Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Engineering a Multienzyme Complex with Synthetic and Mechanistic Goals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Because life at the molecular level is the chemistry of carbon containing compounds, reactions that make carbon-carbon bonds are particularly valuable. A challenge for making compounds from carbon is the formation of closely related versions or isomers as products from a single reaction. The most closely related isomers are called stereoisomers, otherwise identical compounds, but mirror images of each other. The proposal envisions harnessing the power of biological transformations for carbon-carbon bond formation that make single stereoisomers for the production of practical compounds like pharmaceuticals. The reactions would not only be exquisitely specific, but also environmentally friendly, or "green" by using only natural materials and gentle conditions. The research plan involves the re-engineering of proteins using recombinant DNA technology so that they specifically make high-value products. The projects that make up the plan will enable interdisciplinary training of graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and undergraduates in the fields of enzymology, molecular biology, protein engineering, and chemical synthesis.


With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Drs. Frank Jordan and Edgardo T. Farinas, of Rutgers University-Newark Campus and the New Jersey Institute of Technology, respectively, to undertake enzymatic synthesis of chiral alpha-hydroxy ketones for pharmaceuticals, and fine chemicals for synthesis of larger molecules. For the first time the 2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase multienzyme complex (OGHDc), both human and E. coli, and 2-hydroxy-3-oxoadipate synthase from Mycobacterium tuberculosis (HOAS), will be engineered to create these compounds. The principal investigators have already demonstrated that the first OGDHc component (E1o) is an efficient biocatalyst using the physiological substrate. To enhance the power of this carboligation reaction, they will: (1) Engineer residues from the substrate binding site selected from X-ray structures of the E1os and HOAS to accept a variety of substrates for efficient enzymatic synthesis of alpha-hydroxy ketones, with high enantiomeric excess (ee) and yield; (2) Explore alterations in the chemical nature of donor 2-oxo acid and of acceptor aldehyde. (3) Advance the field of biocatalysis by engineering not only E1os but the second E2o core component of OGDHc to accept unnatural substrates leading to acyl-coenzyme A analogues participating in many metabolic pathways; (4) Explore the mechanism of intra-E2o component acyl transfer to coenzyme A.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal objective of the research funded by this grant has been to use enzymes for the synthesis of high value synthetic materials, specifically relying on the expertise of the PI on enzymes utilizing 2-oxoglutaric acid (also known as alpha-ketoglutaric acid). The research is highly interdisciplinary in nature as it entails both enzymatic and chemical reactions, hence the abillity to create enzyme variants (uisng molecuar biology and protein chemistry), and to synthesize substrate analogues, to test them for expanding the scope of the reactions are both essential. The overarching goal is to utilize the ability of enzymes to carry out chemical reactions with very high enantiomeric excess (ee) for the synthesis of chiral compounds.

    Just at the beginning of the grant period, the PI's department hired a very accomplished synthetic organic chemist who joined this program (Michal Szostak, currently an NSF CAREER awardee for an unrelated project). Michal's participation on the project since the second year of the NSF project (starting in the fall of 2015) has been funded by a joint grant from the Rutgers University - Newark Campus Chancellor's SEED grants; as a magnificent leveraging outcome to this NSF grant, we have had Rutgers funds since fall 2015 for a postdoctoral fellow, who has led organic synthetic aspects. The monetary value of this leveraging approaches closely the amount granted us by the NSF.

     The chemical reaction analogue of the carboligase reaction catalyzed by the coenzyme thiamin diphosphate (ThDP) is the cyanide catalyzed benzoin condensation, reactions in which two molecules of benzaldehyde are connected to each other via a newly formed bond between the aldehyde carbon atoms (not to be confused with aldol type condensations involving reactivity at the alpha carbon of carbonyl compounds). The reaction of interest could be construed as a 'crossed benzoin' condensation in which, in our case, a 2-oxo acid substrate (DONOR) undergoes non-oxidative decarboxylation by one of our enzymes, to a ThDP-bound intermediate we call the enamine (synthetic chemists often use the phrase 'Breslow intermediate' honoring the seminal discovery of ThDP mechanisms by R. Breslow). This DONOR then reacts with any variety of aldehydes as ACCEPTORS, which product upon being released from the ThDP on the enzyme leads to chiral alpha-ketols. Perhaps the best-known enzyme of the genre is transketolase in the pentose phosphate metabolic pathway.

      Below are listed the objectives and principal accomplishment:

     A.1. a. Explore alterations in the chemical nature and chain length of DONOR 2-oxo acid A.1.a. We added to our enzyme 'tool box' a brand new enzyme first expressed by our group that we call human E1a, the first component of a new 2-oxo acid dehydrogenase complex with substrate specificity for 2-oxoadipate, thereby lengthening the DONOR class by a CH2 group, with the ability to form glutarylCoA in addition to our earlier goal of succinylCoA.

We have also synthesized a new 2-oxo acid substrate 2-oxo-4-pentenoic acid. This compound is being developed as DONOR for more complex reactions, such that once the chiral alpha-ketol is synthesized, it can be further derivatized, including participation in metathesis reactions.

This new DONOR along with 2-oxovalerate are our models for further studies and could be reacted with the H298D variant of E1o. 

     A.1. b. The range of ACCEPTORS was expanded by expressing and purifying the enzyme MenD, which is specific for 2-oxoglutarate for donor and many aromatic aldehydes as acceptors.

     A.2. a. Engineering of the E. coli OGDHc E2o component to accept non-cognate DONOR substrates. On the E2o component enzyme, we explored the mechanism of transsuccinylation by carrying out site directed mutagenesis and site saturation mutagenesis studies at five active center residues.

The residues Asp374 and His375 were revealed to be the most important ones, the experiments showed that they do not participate as acid-base catalysts, rather as hydrogen bond and structural residues, respectively. This result has changed our view of a reaction whose mechanism was misunderstood for more than 30 years because of a false analogy.

     A.2.b. What is the mechanism of transfer of the succinyl group to CoA in the active center of E2o-ec? Also on the E2o component, we identified the residue essential for substrate specificity in the acyl transfer (succinyl in wild type complex) step, again using site saturation mutagenesis methods. The results allowed the entire complex to handle the two hydrophobic DONORs 2-oxo-4-pentenoic acid and 2-oxovaleric acid, as evidenced by NADH production as a signal of the overall complex reactivity,

     A.3. An important further advance in our entire program on the superfamily of 2-oxo acid dehydrogenase complexes was made with the discovery that we could assemble functional complex from the the two E2o domains, the lipoyl and catalytic (core) domain independently expressed, needing neither covalent linkage, nor the third domain called the peripheral subunit binding domain for assembly. This is indeed welcome finding for both chemoenzymatic synthesis and other studies.
